PURPOSE
The purpose of this policy is to establish requirements for audit and accountability to aid in protecting the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of PeaceHealth's information systems.
DEFINITIONS
•
Caregiver: PeaceHealth employee, volunteer, trainee, and other persons whose conduct, in the performance of work for PeaceHealth, is under the direct control of PeaceHealth, regardless of whether they are paid by PeaceHealth.
•
Confidential Information: Information related to patients, caregivers, or providers, PeaceHealth proprietary information, other information related to PeaceHealth business, and any other information that is protected by law is to be considered strictly confidential unless specified otherwise.
•
Information System: A discrete set of information resources organized for the collection, processing, maintenance, use, sharing, dissemination, or disposition of information.
POLICY
It is the policy of PeaceHealth that the following requirements are implemented to support auditing and accountability for PeaceHealth information systems that process, store, or transmit confidential information:
1.
PeaceHealth logs and monitors information system security-related events such that discrepancies can be identified, unless such logging is not technically feasible, in which case compensating controls are implemented.
a.
Information systems implemented at PeaceHealth log failed and successful login events and access to specified objects.
b.
PeaceHealth selects events and objects to be audited that will affirm that access to confidential information is appropriate and to support future investigations, if required.
c.
At a minimum, the logged events will include successful and failed logins and access to specified high-profile confidential information objects (e.g., ePHI for publicly known individuals).
2.
Content of audit records. Information in the audit logs includes the following:
a.
The type of event;
b.
The time of the event;
c.
The location of the event;
d.
The source of the event; and
e.
Account information associated with the event, if applicable.
3.
Adequate audit storage is allocated to maintain audit log availability for a minimum of 90 days.
4.
Response to audit processing failures. Information systems are configured to alert resource owners of logging failures (e.g., server team, application analysts). Actions in response to audit failures are configured relative to the severity of the failure and the criticality of the information system where the failure occurred.
5.
PeaceHealth analyzes log data for indications of unauthorized access. Evidence of unauthorized access is reported to Information Security. In addition, evidence of unauthorized access of ePHI is reported to the PeaceHealth Privacy Officer.
6.
The information system supports on-demand and after-the fact reporting and review of the prescribed log data defined above. The system does not alter the original log content or time ordering of audit records.
7.
PeaceHealth information systems use internal system clocks to generate time stamps for audit records.
8.
The information system protects audit information (e.g., records, settings, and reports) and audit tools from unauthorized access, modification, and deletion.
9.
PeaceHealth logs actions that require a high level of identity assurance to ensure an individual or process acting on behalf of an individual cannot falsely deny having performed those actions.
10.
PeaceHealth retains the logs defined above in accordance with relevant laws, regulations, and standards.
11.
PeaceHealth information systems:
a.
Provide audit generation capability compliant with this policy;
b.
Allow authorized individuals to select which auditable events are to be audited by specific components of the information system; and
c.
Generate audit records for the events defined in this policy.
COMPLIANCE
Individuals included in the scope of this policy are required to comply with the policy and all associated policies, standards, and procedures. Violations are subject to removal of access and/or corrective action, up to and including termination of employment or other business relationship with PeaceHealth. Any deviations from security standards observed in the production environment must be communicated to the Information Security department immediately upon discovery. If an exception to this policy is necessary, it must be submitted in accordance with the Information Security Policy and Standards Exceptions policy.
HELP
Further information may be obtained by contacting the PeaceHealth Service Desk.
